speaker: moderator
text: Good evening.

speaker: moderator
text: The television and radio stations of the United States and their affiliated stations are proud to provide facilities for a discussion of issues in the current political campaign by the two major candidates for the presidency.

speaker: moderator
text: The candidates need no introduction.

speaker: moderator
text: The Republican candidate, Vice President Richard M. Nixon, and the Democratic candidate, Senator John F. Kennedy.
noun_phrases: ['republican', 'vice president', 'richard m. nixon', 'democratic candidate', 'john f. kennedy']

speaker: moderator
text: According to rules set by the candidates themselves, each man shall make an opening statement of approximately eight minutes' duration and a closing statement of approximately three minutes' duration.

speaker: moderator
text: In between the candidates will answer, or comment upon answers to questions put by a panel of correspondents.

speaker: moderator
text: In this, the first discussion in a series of four uh - joint appearances, the subject-matter has been agreed, will be restricted to internal or domestic American matters.

speaker: moderator
text: And now for the first opening statement by Senator John F. Kennedy.

speaker: kennedy
text: Mr. Smith, Mr. Nixon.

speaker: kennedy
text: In the election of 1860, Abraham Lincoln said the question was whether this nation could exist half-slave or half-free.

speaker: kennedy
text: In the election of 1960, and with the world around us, the question is whether the world will exist half-slave or half-free, whether it will move in the direction of freedom, in the direction of the road that we are taking, or whether it will move in the direction of slavery.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it will depend in great measure upon what we do here in the United States, on the kind of society that we build, on the kind of strength that we maintain.

speaker: kennedy
text: We discuss tonight domestic issues, but I would not want that to be any implication to be given that this does not involve directly our struggle with Mr. Khrushchev for survival.

speaker: kennedy
text: Mr. Khrushchev is in New York, and he maintains the Communist offensive throughout the world because of the productive power of the Soviet Union itselF. The Chinese Communists have always had a large population.

speaker: kennedy
text: But they are important and dangerous now because they are mounting a major effort within their own country.

speaker: kennedy
text: The kind of country we have here, the kind of society we have, the kind of strength we build in the United States will be the defense of freedom.

speaker: kennedy
text: If we do well here, if we meet our obligations, if we're moving ahead, then I think freedom will be secure around the world.

speaker: kennedy
text: If we fail, then freedom fails.

speaker: kennedy
text: Therefore, I think the question before the American people is: Are we doing as much as we can do? Are we as strong as we should be? Are we as strong as we must be if we're going to maintain our independence, and if we're going to maintain and hold out the hand of friendship to those who look to us for assistance, to those who look to us for survival? I should make it very clear that I do not think we're doing enough, that I am not satisfied as an American with the progress that we're making.

speaker: kennedy
text: This is a great country, but I think it could be a greater country; and this is a powerful country, but I think it could be a more powerful country.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied to have fifty percent of our steel-mill capacity unused.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when the United States had last year the lowest rate of economic growth of any major industrialized society in the world.

speaker: kennedy
text: Because economic growth means strength and vitality; it means we're able to sustain our defenses; it means we're able to meet our commitments abroad.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when we have over nine billion dollars worth of food - some of it rotting - even though there is a hungry world, and even though four million Americans wait every month for a food package from the government, which averages five cents a day per individual.

speaker: kennedy
text: I saw cases in West Virginia, here in the United States, where children took home part of their school lunch in order to feed their families because I don't think we're meeting our obligations toward these Americans.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when the Soviet Union is turning out twice as many scientists and engineers as we are.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when many of our teachers are inadequately paid, or when our children go to school part-time shifts.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we should have an educational system second to none.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when I see men like Jimmy Hoffa - in charge of the largest union in the United States - still free.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied when we are failing to develop the natural resources of the United States to the fullest.

speaker: kennedy
text: Here in the United States, which developed the Tennessee Valley and which built the Grand Coulee and the other dams in the Northwest United States at the present rate of hydropower production - and that is the hallmark of an industrialized society - the Soviet Union by 1975 will be producing more power than we are.

speaker: kennedy
text: These are all the things, I think, in this country that can make our society strong, or can mean that it stands still.

speaker: kennedy
text: I'm not satisfied until every American enjoys his full constitutional rights.

speaker: kennedy
text: If a Negro baby is born - and this is true also of Puerto Ricans and Mexicans in some of our cities - he has about one-half as much chance to get through high school as a white baby.

speaker: kennedy
text: He has one-third as much chance to get through college as a white student.

speaker: kennedy
text: He has about a third as much chance to be a professional man, about half as much chance to own a house.

speaker: kennedy
text: He has about uh - four times as much chance that he'll be out of work in his life as the white baby.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we can do better.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't want the talents of any American to go to waste.

speaker: kennedy
text: I know that there are those who want to turn everything over to the government.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't at all.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want the individuals to meet their responsibilities.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I want the states to meet their responsibilities.

speaker: kennedy
text: But I think there is also a national responsibility.

speaker: kennedy
text: The argument has been used against every piece of social legislation in the last twenty-five years.

speaker: kennedy
text: The people of the United States individually could not have developed the Tennessee Valley; collectively they could have.

speaker: kennedy
text: A cotton farmer in Georgia or a peanut farmer or a dairy farmer in Wisconsin and Minnesota, he cannot protect himself against the forces of supply and demand in the market place; but working together in effective governmental programs he can do so.
noun_phrases: ['cotton farmer', 'georgia', 'peanut farmer', 'dairy farmer', 'wisconsin', 'minnesota', 'market place', 'effective governmental programs']

speaker: kennedy
text: Seventeen million Americans, who live over sixty-five on an average Social Security check of about seventy-eight dollars a month, they're not able to sustain themselves individually, but they can sustain themselves through the social security system.
noun_phrases: ['average social security check', 'seventy-eight dollars', 'social security system']

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't believe in big government, but I believe in effective governmental action.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I think that's the only way that the United States is going to maintain its freedom.

speaker: kennedy
text: It's the only way that we're going to move ahead.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we can do a better job.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we're going to have to do a better job if we are going to meet the responsibilities which time and events have placed upon us.

speaker: kennedy
text: We cannot turn the job over to anyone else.

speaker: kennedy
text: If the United States fails, then the whole cause of freedom fails.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I think it depends in great measure on what we do here in this country.

speaker: kennedy
text: The reason Franklin Roosevelt was a good neighbor in Latin America was because he was a good neighbor in the United States.

speaker: kennedy
text: Because they felt that the American society was moving again.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want us to recapture that image.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want people in Latin America and Africa and Asia to start to look to America; to see how we're doing things; to wonder what the resident of the United States is doing; and not to look at Khrushchev, or look at the Chinese Communists.

speaker: kennedy
text: That is the obligation upon our generation.

speaker: kennedy
text: In 1933, Franklin Roosevelt said in his inaugural that this generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think our generation of Americans has the same rendezvous.

speaker: kennedy
text: The question now is: Can freedom be maintained under the most severe tack - attack it has ever known? I think it can be.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I think in the final analysis it depends upon what we do here.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it's time America started moving again.

speaker: moderator
text: And now the opening statement by Vice President Richard M. Nixon

speaker: nixon
text: Mr. Smith, Senator Kennedy.

speaker: nixon
text: The things that Senator Kennedy has said many of us can agree with.

speaker: nixon
text: There is no question but that we cannot discuss our internal affairs in the United States without recognizing that they have a tremendous bearing on our international position.

speaker: nixon
text: There is no question but that this nation cannot stand still; because we are in a deadly competition, a competition not only with the men in the Kremlin, but the men in Peking.

speaker: nixon
text: We're ahead in this competition, as Senator Kennedy, I think, has implied.

speaker: nixon
text: But when you're in a race, the only way to stay ahead is to move ahead.

speaker: nixon
text: And I subscribe completely to the spirit that Senator Kennedy has expressed tonight, the spirit that the United States should move ahead.

speaker: nixon
text: Where, then, do we disagree? I think we disagree on the implication of his remarks tonight and on the statements that he has made on many occasions during his campaign to the effect that the United States has been standing still.

speaker: nixon
text: We heard tonight, for example, the statement made that our growth in national product last year was the lowest of any industrial nation in the world.

speaker: nixon
text: Now last year, of course, was 1958.

speaker: nixon
text: That happened to be a recession year.

speaker: nixon
text: But when we look at the growth of G.N.P.

speaker: nixon
text: this year, a year of recovery, we find that it's six and nine-tenths per cent and one of the highest in the world today.

speaker: nixon
text: More about that later.

speaker: nixon
text: Looking then to this problem of how the United States should move ahead and where the United States is moving, I think it is well that we take the advice of a very famous campaigner: Let's look at the record.

speaker: nixon
text: Is the United States standing still? Is it true that this Administration, as Senator Kennedy has charged, has been an Administration of retreat, of defeat, of stagnation? Is it true that, as far as this country is concerned, in the field of electric power, in all of the fields that he has mentioned, we have not been moving ahead.

speaker: nixon
text: Well, we have a comparison that we can make.

speaker: nixon
text: We have the record of the Truman Administration of seven and a half years and the seven and a half years of the Eisenhower Administration.

speaker: nixon
text: When we compare these two records in the areas that Senator Kennedy has - has discussed tonight, I think we find that America has been moving ahead.

speaker: nixon
text: Let's take schools.

speaker: nixon
text: We have built more schools in these last seven and a half years than we built in the previous seven and a half, for that matter in the previous twenty years.

speaker: nixon
text: Let's take hydroelectric power.

speaker: nixon
text: We have developed more hydroelectric power in these seven and a half years than was developed in any previous administration in history.

speaker: nixon
text: Let us take hospitals.

speaker: nixon
text: We find that more have been built in this Administration than in the previous Administration.

speaker: nixon
text: The same is true of highways.

speaker: nixon
text: Let's put it in terms that all of us can understand.

speaker: nixon
text: We often hear gross national product discussed and in that respect may I say that when we compare the growth in this Administration with that of the previous Administration that then there was a total growth of eleven percent over seven years; in this Administration there has been a total growth of nineteen per cent over seven years.

speaker: nixon
text: That shows that there's been more growth in this Administration than in its predecessor.

speaker: nixon
text: But let's not put it there; let's put it in terms of the average family.

speaker: nixon
text: What has happened to you? We find that your wages have gone up five times as much in the Eisenhower Administration as they did in the Truman Administration.

speaker: nixon
text: What about the prices you pay? We find that the prices you pay went up five times as much in the Truman Administration as they did in the Eisenhower Administration.

speaker: nixon
text: What's the net result of this? This means that the average family income went up fifteen per cent in the Eisenhower years as against two per cent in the Truman years.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, this is not standing still.

speaker: nixon
text: But, good as this record is, may I emphasize it isn't enough.

speaker: nixon
text: A record is never something to stand on.

speaker: nixon
text: It's something to build on.

speaker: nixon
text: And in building on this record, I believe that we have the secret for progress, we know the way to progress.

speaker: nixon
text: And I think, first of all, our own record proves that we know the way.

speaker: nixon
text: Senator Kennedy has suggested that he believes he knows the way.

speaker: nixon
text: I respect the sincerity which he m- which he makes that suggestion.

speaker: nixon
text: But on the other hand, when we look at the various programs that he offers, they do not seem to be new.

speaker: nixon
text: They seem to be simply retreads of the programs of the Truman Administration which preceded it.

speaker: nixon
text: And I would suggest that during the course of the evening he might indicate those areas in which his programs are new, where they will mean more progress than we had then.

speaker: nixon
text: What kind of programs are we for? We are for programs that will expand educational opportunities, that will give to all Americans their equal chance for education, for all of the things which are necessary and dear to the hearts of our people.

speaker: nixon
text: We are for programs, in addition, which will see that our medical care for the aged are - is - are much - is much better handled than it is at the present time.

speaker: nixon
text: Here again, may I indicate that Senator Kennedy and I are not in disagreement as to the aims.

speaker: nixon
text: We both want to help the old people.

speaker: nixon
text: We want to see that they do have adequate medical care.

speaker: nixon
text: The question is the means.

speaker: nixon
text: I think that the means that I advocate will reach that goal better than the means that he advocates.

speaker: nixon
text: I could give better examples, but for - for whatever it is, whether it's in the field of housing, or health, or medical care, or schools, or the eh- development of electric power, we have programs which we believe will move America, move her forward and build on the wonderful record that we have made over these past seven and a half years.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, when we look at these programs, might I suggest that in evaluating them we often have a tendency to say that the test of a program is how much you're spending.

speaker: nixon
text: I will concede that in all the areas to which I have referred Senator Kennedy would have the spe- federal government spend more than I would have it spend.

speaker: nixon
text: I costed out the cost of the Democratic platform.

speaker: nixon
text: It runs a minimum of thirteen and two-tenths billions dollars a year more than we are presently spending to a maximum of eighteen billion dollars a year more than we're presently spending.

speaker: nixon
text: Now the Republican platform will cost more too.

speaker: nixon
text: It will cost a minimum of four billion dollars a year more, a maximum of four and nine-tenths billion dollar a year more than we're presently spending.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, does this mean that his program is better than ours? Not at all.

speaker: nixon
text: Because it isn't a question of how much the federal government spends; it isn't a question of which government does the most.

speaker: nixon
text: It is a question of which administration does the right thing.

speaker: nixon
text: And in our case, I do believe that our programs will stimulate the creative energies of a hundred and eighty million free Americans.

speaker: nixon
text: I believe the programs that Senator Kennedy advocates will have a tendency to stifle those creative energies, I believe in other words, that his program would lead to the stagnation of the motive power that we need in this country to get progress.

speaker: nixon
text: The final point that I would like to make is this: Senator Kennedy has suggested in his speeches that we lack compassion for the poor, for the old, and for others that are unfortunate.

speaker: nixon
text: Let us understand throughout this campaign that his motives and mine are sincere.

speaker: nixon
text: I know what it means to be poor.

speaker: nixon
text: I know what it means to see people who are unemployed.

speaker: nixon
text: I know Senator Kennedy feels as deeply about these problems as I do, but our disagreement is not about the goals for America but only about the means to reach those goals.

speaker: moderator
text: Thank you, Mr. Nixon.

speaker: moderator
text: That completes the opening statements, and now the candidates will answer questions or comment upon one another's answers to questions, put by correspondents of the networks.

speaker: moderator
text: The first question to Senator Kennedy from Mr. Fleming.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator, the Vice President in his campaign has said that you were naive and at times immature.

speaker: moderator
text: He has raised the question of leadership.

speaker: moderator
text: On this issue, why do you think people should vote for you rather than the Vice President?

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, the Vice President and I came to the Congress together 1946; we both served in the Labor Committee.

speaker: kennedy
text: I've been there now for fourteen years, the same period of time that he has, so that our experience in uh - government is comparable.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, I think the question is uh - what are the programs that we advocate, what is the party record that we lead? I come out of the Democratic party, which in this century has produced Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman, and which supported and sustained these programs which I've discussed tonight.

speaker: kennedy
text: Mr. Nixon comes out of the Republican party.

speaker: kennedy
text: He was nominated by it.

speaker: kennedy
text: And it is a fact that through most of these last twenty-five years the Republican leadership has opposed federal aid for education, medical care for the aged, development of the Tennessee Valley, development of our natural resources.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think Mr. Nixon is an effective leader of his party.

speaker: kennedy
text: I hope he would grant me the same.

speaker: kennedy
text: The question before us is: which point of view and which party do we want to lead the United States?

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Nixon, would you like to comment on that statement?

speaker: nixon
text: I have no comment.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vice President, your campaign stresses the value of your eight year experience, and the question arises as to whether that experience was as an observer or as a participant or as an initiator of policy-making.

speaker: moderator
text: Would you tell us please specifically what major proposals you have made in the last eight years that have been adopted by the Administration?

speaker: nixon
text: It would be rather difficult to cover them in eight and- in two and a half minutes.

speaker: nixon
text: I would suggest that these proposals could be mentioned.

speaker: nixon
text: First, after each of my foreign trips I have made recommendations that have been adopted.

speaker: nixon
text: For example, after my first trip abroad - abroad, I strongly recommended that we increase our exchange programs particularly as they related to exchange of persons of leaders in the labor field and in the information field.

speaker: nixon
text: After my trip to South America, I made recommendations that a separate inter-American lending agency be set up which the South American nations would like much better than a lend- than to participate in the lending agencies which treated all the countries of the world the same.

speaker: nixon
text: Uh - I have made other recommendations after each of the other trips; for example, after my trip abroad to Hungary I made some recommendations with regard to the Hungarian refugee situation which were adopted, not only by the President but some of them were enacted into law by the Congress.

speaker: nixon
text: Within the Administration, as a chairman of the President's Committee on Price Stability and Economic Growth, I have had the opportunity to make recommendations which have been adopted within the Administration and which I think have been reasonably effective.

speaker: nixon
text: I know Senator Kennedy suggested in his speech at Cleveland yesterday that that committee had not been particularly effective.

speaker: nixon
text: I would only suggest that while we do not take the credit for it - I would not presume to - that since that committee has been formed the price line has been held very well within the United States.

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, I would say in the latter that the - and that's what I found uh - somewhat unsatisfactory about the figures uh - Mr. Nixon, that you used in your previous speech, when you talked about the Truman Administration.

speaker: kennedy
text: You - Mr. Truman came to office in nineteen uh - forty-four and at the end of the war, and uh - difficulties that were facing the United States during that period of transition - 1946 when price controls were lifted - so it's rather difficult to use an overall figure taking those seven and a half years and comparing them to the last eight years.

speaker: kennedy
text: I prefer to take the overall percentage record of the last twenty years of the Democrats and the eight years of the Republicans to show an overall period of growth.

speaker: kennedy
text: In regard to uh - price stability uh - I'm not aware that that committee did produce recommendations that ever were certainly before the Congress from the point of view of legislation in regard to controlling prices.

speaker: kennedy
text: In regard to the exchange of students and labor unions, I am chairman of the subcommittee on Africa and I think that one of the most unfortunate phases of our policy towards that country was the very minute number of exchanges that we had.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it's true of Latin America also.

speaker: kennedy
text: We did come forward with a program of students for the Congo of over three hundred which was more than the federal government had for all of Africa the previous year, so that I don't think that uh - we have moved at least in those two areas with sufficient vigor.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Senator Kennedy from Mr. Warren.

speaker: moderator
text: Uh - Senator Kennedy, during your brief speech a few minutes ago you mentioned farm surpluses.

speaker: kennedy
text: That's correct.

speaker: moderator
text: I'd like to ask this

speaker: moderator
text: Lots of people, I think, don't understand why the government pays farmers for not producing certain crops or paying farmers if they overproduce for that matter.

speaker: moderator
text: Now, let me ask, sir, why can't the farmer operate like the business man who operates a factory? If an auto company overproduces a certain model car Uncle Sam doesn't step in and buy up the surplus.
noun_phrases: ["ca n't", 'business man', 'auto company overproduces', 'certain model car', 'uncle sam', "n't step"]

speaker: moderator
text: Why this constant courting of the farmer?

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, because I think that if the federal government moved out of the program and withdrew its supports uh - then I think you would have complete uh - economic chaos.

speaker: kennedy
text: The farmer plants in the spring and harvests in the fall.

speaker: kennedy
text: There are hundreds of thousands of them.

speaker: kennedy
text: They really don't - they're not able to control their market very well.

speaker: kennedy
text: They bring their crops in or their livestock in, many of them about the same time.

speaker: kennedy
text: They have only a few purchasers that buy their milk or their hogs - a few large companies in many cases - and therefore the farmer is not in a position to bargain very effectively in the market place.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think the experience of the twenties has shown what a free market could do to agriculture.

speaker: kennedy
text: And if the agricultural economy collapses, then the economy of the rest of the United States sooner or later will collapse.

speaker: kennedy
text: The farmers are the number one market for the automobile industry of the United States.

speaker: kennedy
text: The automobile industry is the number one market for steel.

speaker: kennedy
text: So if the farmers' economy continues to decline as sharply as it has in recent years, then I think you would have a recession in the rest of the country.

speaker: kennedy
text: So I think the case for the government intervention is a good one.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, my objection to present farm policy is that there are no effective controls to bring supply and demand into better balance.

speaker: kennedy
text: The dropping of the support price in order to limit production does not work, and we now have the highest uh - surpluses - nine billion dollars worth.

speaker: kennedy
text: We've had a uh - higher tax load from the Treasury for the farmer in the last few years with the lowest farm income in many years.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think that this farm policy has failed.

speaker: kennedy
text: In my judgment the only policy that will work will be for effective supply and demand to be in balance.

speaker: kennedy
text: And that can only be done through governmental action.

speaker: kennedy
text: I therefore suggest that in those basic commodities which are supported, that the federal government, after endorsement by the farmers in that commodity, attempt to bring supply and demand into balance - attempt effective production controls - so that we won't have that five or six per cent surplus which breaks the price fifteen or twenty per cent.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think Mr. Benson's program has failed.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I must say, after reading the Vice President's speech before the farmers, as he read mine, I don't believe that it's very much different from Mr. Benson's.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't think it provides effective governmental controls.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think the support prices are tied to the average market price of the last three years, which was Mr. Benson's theory.

speaker: kennedy
text: I therefore do not believe that this is a sharp enough breach with the past to give us any hope of success for the future.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Nixon, comment?

speaker: nixon
text: I of course disagree with Senator Kennedy insofar as his suggestions as to what should be done uh - with re- on the farm program.

speaker: nixon
text: He has made the suggestion that what we need is to move in the direction of more government controls, a suggestion that would also mean raising prices uh - that the consumers pay for products and im- and imposing upon the farmers uh - controls on acreage even far more than they have today.

speaker: nixon
text: I think this is the wrong direction.

speaker: nixon
text: I don't think this has worked in the past; I do not think it will work in the future.

speaker: nixon
text: The program that I have advocated is one which departs from the present program that we have in this respect.

speaker: nixon
text: It recognizes that the government has a responsibility to get the farmer out of the trouble he presently is in because the government got him into it.

speaker: nixon
text: And that's the fundamental reason why we can't let the farmer go by himself at the present time.

speaker: nixon
text: The farmer produced these surpluses because the government asked him to through legislation during the war.

speaker: nixon
text: Now that we have these surpluses, it's our responsibility to indemnify the farmer during that period that we get rid of the farmer uh - the surpluses.

speaker: nixon
text: Until we get the surpluses off the farmer's back, however, we should have a program such as I announced, which will see that farm income holds up.

speaker: nixon
text: But I would propose holding that income up not through a type of program that Senator Kennedy has suggested that would raise prices, but one that would indemnify the farmer, pay the farmer in kind uh - from the products which are in surplus.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Vice President Nixon from Mr. Vanocur.

speaker: moderator
text: Uh - Mr. Vice President, since the question of executive leadership is a very important campaign issue, I'd like to follow Mr. Novins' question.

speaker: moderator
text: Now, Republican campaign slogans - you'll see them on signs around the country as you did last week - say it's experience that counts - that's over a picture of yourself; sir uh - implying that you've had more governmental executive decision-making uh - experience than uh - your opponent.
noun_phrases: ['republican', 'campaign slogans', "'s experience", 'sir uh', 'governmental executive decision-making uh']

speaker: moderator
text: Now, in his news conference on August twenty-fourth, President Eisenhower was asked to give one example of a major idea of yours that he adopted.

speaker: moderator
text: His reply was, and I'm quoting; "If you give me a week I might think of one.

speaker: moderator
text: I don't remember." Now that was a month ago, sir, and the President hasn't brought it up since, and I'm wondering, sir, if you can clarify which version is correct - the one put out by Republican campaign leaders or the one put out by President Eisenhower?

speaker: nixon
text: Well, I would suggest, Mr. Vanocur, that uh - if you know the President, that was probably a facetious remarK. Uh - I would also suggest that insofar as his statement is concerned, that I think it would be improper for the President of the United States to disclose uh - the instances in which members of his official family had made recommendations, as I have made them through the years to him, which he has accepted or rejected.

speaker: nixon
text: The President has always maintained and very properly so that he is entitled to get what advice he wants from his cabinet and from his other advisers without disclosing that to anybody - including as a matter of fact the Congress.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, I can only say this.

speaker: nixon
text: Through the years I have sat in the National Security Council.

speaker: nixon
text: I have been in the cabinet.

speaker: nixon
text: I have met with the legislative leaders.

speaker: nixon
text: I have met with the President when he made the great decisions with regard to Lebanon, Quemoy and Matsu, other matters.

speaker: nixon
text: The President has asked for my advice.

speaker: nixon
text: I have given it.

speaker: nixon
text: Sometimes my advice has been taken.

speaker: nixon
text: Sometimes it has not.

speaker: nixon
text: I do not say that I have made the decisions.

speaker: nixon
text: And I would say that no president should ever allow anybody else to make the major decisions, The president only makes the decisions.

speaker: nixon
text: All that his advisers do is to give counsel when he asks for it.

speaker: nixon
text: As far as what experience counts and whether that is experience that counts, that isn't for me to say.

speaker: nixon
text: Uh - I can only say that my experience is there for the people to consider; Senator Kennedy's is there for the people to consider.

speaker: nixon
text: As he pointed out, we came to the Congress in the same year.

speaker: nixon
text: His experience has been different from mine.

speaker: nixon
text: Mine has been in the executive branch.

speaker: nixon
text: His has been in the legislative branch.

speaker: nixon
text: I would say that the people now have the opportunity to evaluate his as against mine and I think both he and I are going to abide by whatever the people decide.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy.

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, I'll just say that the question is of experience and the question also is uh - what our judgment is of the future, and what our goals are for the United States, and what ability we have to implement those goals.

speaker: kennedy
text: Abraham Lincoln came to the presidency in 1860 after a rather little known uh - session in the House of Representatives and after being defeated for the Senate in fifty-eight and was a distinguished president.

speaker: kennedy
text: There's no certain road to the presidency.

speaker: kennedy
text: There are no guarantees that uh - if you take uh - one road or another that you will be a successful president.

speaker: kennedy
text: I have been in the Congress for fourteen years.

speaker: kennedy
text: I have voted in the last uh - eight years uh - and the Vice President was uh - presiding over the Senate and meeting his other responsibilities.

speaker: kennedy
text: I have met met uh - decisions over eight hundred times on matters which affect not only the domestic security of the United States, but as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

speaker: kennedy
text: The question really is: which candidate and which party can meet the problems that the United States is going to face in the sixties?

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Senator Kennedy from Mr. Novins.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy, in connection with these problems of the future that you speak of, and the program that you enunciated earlier in your direct talk, you call for expanding some of the welfare programs for schools, for teacher salaries, medical care, and so forth; but you also call for reducing the federal debt.

speaker: moderator
text: And I'm wondering how you, if you're president in January, would go about paying the bill for all this.

speaker: moderator
text: Does this mean that you?

speaker: kennedy
text: I didn't indicate.

speaker: kennedy
text: I did not advocate reducing the federal debt because I don't believe that you're going to be able to reduce the federal debt very much in nineteen sixty-one, two, or three.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think you have heavy obligations which affect our security, which we're going to have to meet.

speaker: kennedy
text: And therefore I've never suggested we should uh - be able to retire the debt substantially, or even at all in nineteen sixty-one or two.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator, I believe in - in one of your speeches -

speaker: kennedy
text: No, never.

speaker: moderator
text: - you suggested that reducing the interest rate would help toward -

speaker: kennedy
text: No.

speaker: kennedy
text: No.

speaker: kennedy
text: In my judgment, the hard money, tight money policy, fiscal policy of this Administration has contributed to the slow-down in our economy, which helped bring the recession of fifty-four; which made the recession of fifty-eight rather intense, and which has slowed, somewhat, our economic activity in 1960.

speaker: kennedy
text: What I have talked about, however, the kind of programs that I've talked about, in my judgment, are uh - fiscally sound.

speaker: kennedy
text: Medical care for the aged, I would put under social security.

speaker: kennedy
text: The Vice President and I disagree on this.

speaker: kennedy
text: The program - the Javits-Nixon or the Nixon-Javits program - would have cost, if fully used uh - six hundred million dollars by the government per year, and six hundred million dollars by the state.

speaker: kennedy
text: The program which I advocated, which failed by five votes in the United States Senate, would have put medical care for the aged in Social Security, and would have been paid for through the Social Security System and the Social Security tax.
noun_phrases: ['medical care', 'social security', 'social security system', 'social security tax']

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, I support federal aid to education and federal aid for teachers' salaries.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think that's a good investment.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we're going to have to do it.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I think to heap the burden further on the property tax, which is already strained in many of our communities, will provide, will make sh- insure, in my opinion, that many of our children will not be adequately educated, and many of our teachers not adequately compensated.

speaker: kennedy
text: There is no greater return to an economy or to a society than an educational system second to none.

speaker: kennedy
text: On the question of the development of natural resources, I would pay as you go in the sense that they would be balanced and the power revenues would bring back sufficient money to finance the projects, in the same way as the Tennessee Valley.

speaker: kennedy
text: I believe in the balanced budget.

speaker: kennedy
text: And the only conditions under which I would unbalance the budget would be if there was a grave national emergency or a serious recession.

speaker: kennedy
text: Otherwise, with a steady rate of economic growth - and Mr. Nixon and Mr. Rockefeller, in their meeting, said a five per cent economic growth would bring by 1962 ten billion dollars extra in tax revenues.

speaker: kennedy
text: Whatever is brought in, I think that we can finance essential programs within a balanced budget, if business remains orderly.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Nixon, your comment?

speaker: nixon
text: Yes.

speaker: nixon
text: I think what Mr. Novins was referring to was not one of Senator Kennedy's speeches, but the Democratic platform, which did mention cutting the national debt.

speaker: nixon
text: I think, too, that it should be pointed out that of course it is not possible, particularly under the proposals that Senator Kennedy has advocated, either to cut the national debt or to reduce taxes.

speaker: nixon
text: As a matter of fact it will be necessary to raise taxes.

speaker: nixon
text: As Senator Kennedy points out that as far as his one proposal is concerned - the one for medical care for the aged - that that would be financed out of Social Security.

speaker: nixon
text: That, however, is raising taxes for those who pay Social Security.

speaker: nixon
text: He points out that he would make pay-as-you-go be the basis for our natural resources development.

speaker: nixon
text: Where our natural resources development - which I also support, incidentally, however - whenever you uh - uh - in - in - uh - appropriates money for one of these projects, you have to pay now and appropriate the money and the eh- while they eventually do pay out, it doesn't mean that you - the government doesn't have to put out the money this year.

speaker: nixon
text: And so I would say that in all of these proposals Senator Kennedy has made, they will result in one of two things: either he has to raise taxes or he has to unbalance the budget.

speaker: nixon
text: If he unbalances the budget, that means you have inflation, and that will be, of course, a very cruel blow to the very people - the older people - that we've been talking about.

speaker: nixon
text: As far as aid for school construction is concerned, I favor that, as Senator Kennedy did, in January of this year, when he said he favored that rather than aid to s- teacher salaries.

speaker: nixon
text: I favor that because I believe that's the best way to aid our schools without running any risk whatever of the federal government telling our teachers what to teach.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Vice President Nixon from Mr. Warren.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vice President you mentioned schools and it was just yesterday I think you asked for a crash program to raise education standards, and this evening you talked about advances in education.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vice President, you said - it was back in 1957 - that salaries paid to school teachers were nothing short of a national disgrace.

speaker: moderator
text: Higher salaries for teachers, you added, were important and if the situation wasn't corrected it could lead to a national disaster.

speaker: moderator
text: And yet, you refused to vote in the Senate in order to break a tie vote when that single vote, if it had been yes, would have granted salary increases to teachers.

speaker: moderator
text: I wonder if you could explain that, sir.

speaker: nixon
text: I'm awfully glad you ge- got that question because as you know I got into it at the last of my other question and wasn't able to complete the argument.

speaker: nixon
text: Uh - I think that the reason that I voted against having the federal government uh - pay teachers' salaries was probably the very reason that concerned Senator Kennedy when in January of this year, in his kick-off press conference, he said that he favored aid for school construction, but at that time did not feel that there should be aid for teachers' salaries - at least that's the way I read his remarks.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, why should there be any question about the federal government aiding s- teachers' salaries? Why did Senator Kennedy take that position then? Why do I take it now? We both took it then, and I take it now, for this reason: we want higher teachers' salaries.

speaker: nixon
text: We need higher teachers' salaries.

speaker: nixon
text: But we also want our education to be free of federal control.

speaker: nixon
text: When the federal government gets the power to pay teachers, inevitably in my opinion, it will acquire the power to set standards and to tell the teachers what to teach.

speaker: nixon
text: I think this would be bad for the country; I think it would be bad for the teaching profession.

speaker: nixon
text: There is another point that should be made.

speaker: nixon
text: I favor higher salaries for teachers.

speaker: nixon
text: But, as Senator Kennedy said in January of this year in this same press conference, the way that you get higher salaries for teachers is to support school construction, which means that all of the local school districts in the various states then have money which is freed to raise the standards for teachers' salaries.
noun_phrases: ['kennedy', 'january', 'press conference', 'support school construction', 'local school districts', 'various states']

speaker: nixon
text: I should also point out this; once you put the responsibility on the federal government for paying a portion of teachers' salaries, your local communities and your states are not going to meet the responsibility as much as they should.

speaker: nixon
text: I believe, in other words, that we have seen the local communities and the state assuming more of that responsibility.

speaker: nixon
text: Teachers' salaries very fortunately have gone up fifty percent in the last eight years as against only a thirty-four percent rise for other salaries.

speaker: nixon
text: This is not enough; it should be more.

speaker: nixon
text: But I do not believe that the way to get more salaries for teachers is to have the federal government get in with a massive program.

speaker: nixon
text: My objection here is not the cost in dollars.

speaker: nixon
text: My objection here is the potential cost in controls and eventual freedom for the American people by giving the federal government power over education, and that is the greatest power a government can have.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy's comment?

speaker: kennedy
text: When uh - the Vice President quotes me in January, sixty, I do not believe the federal government should pay directly teachers' salaries, but that was not the issue before the Senate in February.

speaker: kennedy
text: The issue before the Senate was that the money would be given to the state.

speaker: kennedy
text: The state then could determine whether the money would be spent for school construction or teacher salaries.

speaker: kennedy
text: On that question the Vice President and I disagreed.

speaker: kennedy
text: I voted in favor of that proposal and supported it strongly, because I think that that provided assistance to our teachers for their salaries without any chance of federal control and it is on that vote that th- Mr. Nixon and I disagreed, and his tie vote uh - defeated his breaking the tie defeated the proposal.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't want the federal government paying teachers' salaries directly.

speaker: kennedy
text: But if the money will go to the states and the states can then determine whether it shall go for school construction or for teachers' salaries, in my opinion you protect the local authority over the school board and the school committee.

speaker: kennedy
text: And therefore I think that was a sound proposal and that is why I supported it and I regret that it did not pass.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, there have been statements made that uh - the Democratic platform would cost a good deal of money and that I am in favor of unbalancing the budget.

speaker: kennedy
text: That is wholly wrong, wholly in error, and it is a fact that in the last eight years the Democratic Congress has reduced the appropri- the requests for the appropriations by over ten billion dollars.

speaker: kennedy
text: That is not my view and I think it ought to be stated very clearly on the record.

speaker: kennedy
text: My view is that you can do these programs - and they should be carefully drawn - within a balanced budget if our economy is moving ahead.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Senator Kennedy from Mr. Vanocur.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator, you've been promising the voters that if you are elected president you'll try and push through Congress bills on medical aid to the aged, a comprehensive minimum hourly wage bill, federal aid to education.

speaker: moderator
text: Now, in the August post-convention session of the Congress, when you at least held up the possibility you could one day be president and when you had overwhelming majorities, especially in the Senate, you could not get action on these bills.

speaker: moderator
text: Now how do you feel that you'll be able to get them in January -

speaker: kennedy
text: Well as you take the bills -

speaker: moderator
text: - if you weren't able to get them in August?

speaker: kennedy
text: If I may take the bills, we did pass in the Senate a bill uh - to provide a dollar twenty-five cent minimum wage.

speaker: kennedy
text: It failed because the House did not pass it and the House failed by eleven votes.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I might say that two-thirds of the Republicans in the House voted against a dollar twenty-five cent minimum wage and a majority of the Democrats sustained it - nearly two-thirds of them voted for the dollar twenty-five.

speaker: kennedy
text: We were threatened by a veto if we passed a dollar and a quarter - it's extremely difficult with the great power that the president does to pass any bill when the president is opposed to it.

speaker: kennedy
text: All the president needs to sustain his veto of any bill is one-third plus one in either the House or the Senate.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, we passed a federal aid to education bill in the Senate.

speaker: kennedy
text: It failed to came to the floor of the House of Representatives.

speaker: kennedy
text: It was killed in the Rules Committee.

speaker: kennedy
text: And it is a fact in the August session that the four members of the Rules Committee who were Republicans joining with two Democrats voted against sending the aid to education bill to the floor of the House.

speaker: kennedy
text: Four Democrats voted for it.

speaker: kennedy
text: Every Republican on the Rules Committee voted against sending that bill to be considered by the members of the House of Representatives.

speaker: kennedy
text: Thirdly, on medical care for the aged, this is the same fight that's been going on for twenty-five years in Social Security.

speaker: kennedy
text: We wanted to tie it to Social Security.

speaker: kennedy
text: We offered an amendment to do so.

speaker: kennedy
text: Forty-four Democrats voted for it, one Republican voted for it.

speaker: kennedy
text: And we were informed at the time it came to a vote that if it was adopted the President of the United States would veto it.

speaker: kennedy
text: In my judgment, a vigorous Democratic president supported by a Democratic majority in the House and Senate can win the support for these programs.

speaker: kennedy
text: But if you send a Republican president and a Democratic majority and the threat of a veto hangs over the Congress, in my judgment you will continue what happened in the August session, which is a clash of parties and inaction.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Nixon, comment?

speaker: nixon
text: Well obviously my views are a little different.

speaker: nixon
text: First of all, I don't see how it's possible for a one-third of a body, such as the Republicans have in the House and the Senate to stop two-thirds, if the two-thirds are adequately led.

speaker: nixon
text: I would say, too, that when Senator Kennedy refers to the action of the House Rules Committee, there are eight Democrats on that committee and four Republicans.

speaker: nixon
text: It would seem to me again that it is very difficult to blame the four Republicans for the eight Democrats' not getting a something through that particular committee.

speaker: nixon
text: I would say further that to blame the President in his veto power for the inability of the Senator and his colleagues to get action in this special session uh - misses the marK. When the president exercises his veto power, he has to have the people upo- behind him, not just a third of the Congress.
noun_phrases: ['veto power', 'special session uh', 'president exercises', 'veto power', 'people upo-', 'congress']

speaker: nixon
text: Because let's consider it.

speaker: nixon
text: If the majority of the members of the Congress felt that these particular proposals were good issues - the majority of those who were Democrats - why didn't they pass them and send to the President and get a veto and have an issue? The reason why these particular bills in these various fields that have been mentioned were not passed was not because the President was against them; it was because the people were against them.

speaker: nixon
text: It was because they were too extreme.

speaker: nixon
text: And I am convinced that the alternate proposals that I have, that the Republicans have in the field of health, in the field of education, in the field of welfare, because they are not extreme, because they will accomplish the end uh - without too great cost in dollars or in freedom, that they could get through the next Congress.

speaker: moderator
text: The next question to Vice President Nixon fa- from Mr. Fleming.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vice President, do I take it then you believe that you can work better with Democratic majorities in the House and Senate than Senator Kennedy could work with Democratic majorities in the House and Senate?

speaker: nixon
text: I would say this: that we, of course, expect to pick up some seats in both in the House and the Senate.

speaker: nixon
text: Uh - We would hope to control the House, to get a majority in the House uh - in this election.

speaker: nixon
text: We cannot, of course, control the Senate.

speaker: nixon
text: I would say that a president will be able to lead - a president will be able to get his program through - to the effect that he has the support of the country, the support of the people.

speaker: nixon
text: Sometimes we - we get the opinion that in getting programs through the House or the Senate it's purely a question of legislative finagling and all that sort of thing.

speaker: nixon
text: It isn't really that.

speaker: nixon
text: Whenever a majority of the people are for a program, the House and the Senate responds to it.

speaker: nixon
text: And whether this House and Senate, in the next session is Democratic or Republican, if the country will have voted for the candidate for the presidency and for the proposals that he has made, I believe that you will find that the president, if it were a Republican, as it would be in my case, would be able to get his program through that Congress.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, I also say that as far as Senator Kennedy's proposals are concerned, that, again, the question is not simply one of uh - a presidential veto stopping programs.

speaker: nixon
text: You must always remember that a president can't stop anything unless he has the people behind him.

speaker: nixon
text: And the reason President Eisenhower's vetoes have been sustained - the reason the Congress does not send up bills to him which they think will be vetoed - is because the people and the Congress, the majority of them, know the country is behind the President.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy.

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, now let's look at these bills that the Vice President suggests were too extreme.

speaker: kennedy
text: One was a bill for a dollar twenty-five cents an hour for anyone who works in a store or company that has a million dollars a year business.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't think that's extreme at all; and yet nearly two-thirds to three-fourths of the Republicans in the House of Representatives voted against that proposal.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly was the federal aid to education bill.

speaker: kennedy
text: It - it was a very uh - because of the defeat of teacher salaries, it was not a bill that uh - met in my opinion the need.

speaker: kennedy
text: The fact of the matter is it was a bill that was less than you recommended, Mr. Nixon, this morning in your proposal.

speaker: kennedy
text: It was not an extreme bill and yet we could not get one Republican to join, at least I think four of the eight Democrats voted to send it to the floor of the House - not one Republican - and they joined with those Democrats who were opposed to it.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't say the Democrats are united in their support of the program.

speaker: kennedy
text: But I do say a majority are.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I say a majority of the Republicans are opposed to it.

speaker: kennedy
text: The third is medical care for the aged which is tied to Social Security, which is financed out of Social Security funds.

speaker: kennedy
text: It does not put a deficit on the Treasury.

speaker: kennedy
text: The proposal advanced by you and by Mr. Javits would have cost six hundred millions of dollars - Mr. Rockefeller rejected it in New York, said he didn't agree with the financing at all, said it ought to be on Social Security.

speaker: kennedy
text: So these are three programs which are quite moderate.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it shows the difference between the two parties.

speaker: kennedy
text: One party is ready to move in these programs.

speaker: kennedy
text: The other party gives them lip service.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Warren's question for Senator Kennedy.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy, on another subject, Communism is so often described as an ideology or a belief that exists somewhere other than in the United States.

speaker: moderator
text: Let me ask you, sir: just how serious a threat to our national security are these Communist subversive activities in the United States today?

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, I think they're serious.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it's a matter that we should continue to uh - give uh - great care and attention to.

speaker: kennedy
text: We should support uh - the laws which the United States has passed in order to protect us from uh - those who would destroy us from within.

speaker: kennedy
text: We should sustain uh - the Department of Justice in its efforts and the F.B.I., and we should be continually alert.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think if the United States is maintaining a strong society here in the United States, I think that we can meet any internal threat.

speaker: kennedy
text: The major threat is external and will continue.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Nixon, comment?

speaker: nixon
text: I agree with Senator Kennedy's appraisal generally in this respect.

speaker: nixon
text: The question of Communism within the United States has been one that has worried us in the past.

speaker: nixon
text: It is one that will continue to be a problem for years to come.

speaker: nixon
text: We have to remember that the cold war that Mr. Khrushchev is waging and his colleagues are waging, is waged all over the world and it's waged right here in the United States.

speaker: nixon
text: That's why we have to continue to be alert.

speaker: nixon
text: It is also essential in being alert that we be fair; fair because by being fair we uphold the very freedoms that the Communists would destroy.

speaker: nixon
text: We uphold the standards of conduct which they would never follow.

speaker: nixon
text: And, in this connection, I think that uh - we must look to the future having in mind the fact that we fight Communism at home not only by our laws to deal with Communists uh - the few who do become Communists and the few who do become tra- fellow travelers, but we also fight Communism at home by moving against those various injustices which exist in our society which the Communists feed upon.

speaker: nixon
text: And in that connection I again would say that while Senator Kennedy says we are for the status quo, I do believe that he uh - would agree that I am just as sincere in believing that my proposals for federal aid to education, my proposals for health care are just as sincerely held as his.

speaker: nixon
text: The question again is not one of goals - we're for those goals - it's one of means.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vanocur's question for Vice President Nixon.

speaker: moderator
text: Mr. Vice President uh - in one of your earlier statements you said we've moved ahead, we've built more schools, we've built more hospitals.

speaker: moderator
text: Now, sir, isn't it true that the building of more schools is a local matter for financing? Uh - Were you claiming that the Eisenhower Administration was responsible for the building of these schools, or is it the local school districts that provide for it?

speaker: nixon
text: Not at all.

speaker: nixon
text: As a matter of fact your question brings out a point that I am very glad to make.

speaker: nixon
text: Too often in appraising whether we are moving ahead or not we think only of what the federal government is doing.

speaker: nixon
text: Now that isn't the test of whether America moves.

speaker: nixon
text: The test of whether America moves is whether the federal government, plus the state government, plus the local government, plus the biggest segment of all - individual enterprise - moves.

speaker: nixon
text: We have for example a gross national product of approximately five hundred billion dollars.

speaker: nixon
text: Roughly a hundred billion to a hundred and a quarter billion of that is the result of government activity.

speaker: nixon
text: Four hundred billion, approximately, is a result of what individuals do.

speaker: nixon
text: Now, the reason the Eisenhower Administration has moved, the reason that we've had the funds, for example, locally to build the schools, and the hospitals, and the highways, to make the progress that we have, is because this Administration has encouraged individual enterprise; and it has resulted in the greatest expansion of the private sector of the economy that has ever been witnessed in an eight-year period.

speaker: nixon
text: And that is growth.

speaker: nixon
text: That is the growth that we are looking for; it is the growth that this Administration has supported and that its policies have stimulated.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy.

speaker: kennedy
text: Well, I must say that the reason that the schools have been constructed is because the local school districts were willing to increase the property taxes to a tremendously high figure - in my opinion, almost to the point of diminishing returns in order to sustain these schools.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, I think we have a rich uh - country.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I think we have a powerful country.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think what we have to do, however, is have the president and the leadership set before our country exactly what we must do in the next decade, if we're going to maintain our security in education, in economic growth, in development of natural resources.

speaker: kennedy
text: The Soviet Union is making great gains.

speaker: kennedy
text: It isn't enough to compare what might have been done eight years ago, or ten years ago, or fifteen years ago, or twenty years ago.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want to compare what we're doing with what our adversaries are doing, so that by the year 1970 the United States is ahead in education, in health, in building, in homes, in economic strength.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think that's the big assignment, the big task, the big function of the federal government.

speaker: moderator
text: Can I have the summation time please? We've completed our questions and our comments, and in just a moment, we'll have the summation time.

speaker: moderator
text: This will allow three minutes and twenty seconds for the summation by each candidate.

speaker: moderator
text: Three minutes and twenty seconds for each candidate.

speaker: moderator
text: Vice President Nixon, will you make the first summation?

speaker: nixon
text: Thank you, Mr. Smith.

speaker: nixon
text: Senator Kennedy.

speaker: nixon
text: First of all, I think it is well to put in perspective where we really do stand with regard to the Soviet Union in this whole matter of growth.

speaker: nixon
text: The Soviet Union has been moving faster than we have.

speaker: nixon
text: But the reason for that is obvious.

speaker: nixon
text: They start from a much lower base.

speaker: nixon
text: Although they have been moving faster in growth than we have, we find, for example, today that their total gross national product is only forty-four per cent of our total gross national product.

speaker: nixon
text: That's the same percentage that it was twenty years ago.

speaker: nixon
text: And as far as the absolute gap is concerned, we find that the United States is even further ahead than it was twenty years ago.

speaker: nixon
text: Is this any reason for complacency? Not at all Because these are determined men.

speaker: nixon
text: They are fanatical men.

speaker: nixon
text: And we have to get the very most of uh - out uh - out of our economy.

speaker: nixon
text: I agree with Senator Kennedy completely on that score.

speaker: nixon
text: Where we disagree is in the means that we would use to get the most out of our economy.

speaker: nixon
text: I respectfully submit that Senator Kennedy too often would rely too much on the federal government, on what it would do to solve our problems, to stimulate growth.

speaker: nixon
text: I believe that when we examine the Democratic platform, when we examine the proposals that he has discussed tonight, when we compare them with the proposals that I have made, that these proposals that he makes would not result in greater growth for this country than would be the case if we followed the programs that I have advocated.

speaker: nixon
text: There are many of the points that he has made that I would like to comment upon.

speaker: nixon
text: The one in the field of health is worth mentioning.

speaker: nixon
text: Our health program - the one that Senator Javits and other Republican Senators, as well as I supported - is one that provides for all people over sixty-five who want health insurance, the opportunity to have it if they want it.

speaker: nixon
text: It provides a choice of having either government insurance or private insurance.

speaker: nixon
text: But it compels nobody to have insurance who does not want it.

speaker: nixon
text: His program under Social Security, would require everybody who had Social Security to take government health insurance whether he wanted it or not.

speaker: nixon
text: And it would not cover several million people who are not covered by Social Security at all.

speaker: nixon
text: Here is one place where I think that our program does a better job than his.

speaker: nixon
text: The other point that I would make is this: this downgrading of how much things cost I think many of our people will understand better when they look at what happened when - during the Truman Administration when the government was spending more than it took in - we found savings over a lifetime eaten up by inflation.

speaker: nixon
text: We found the people who could least afford it - people on retired incomes uh - people on fixed incomes - we found them unable to meet their bills at the end of the month.

speaker: nixon
text: It is essential that a man who's president of this country certainly stand for every program that will mean for growth.

speaker: nixon
text: And I stand for programs that will mean growth and progress.

speaker: nixon
text: But it is also essential that he not allow a dollar spent that could be better spent by the people themselves.

speaker: moderator
text: Senator Kennedy, your conclusion.

speaker: kennedy
text: The point was made by Mr. Nixon that the Soviet production is only forty-four percent of ours.

speaker: kennedy
text: I must say that forty-four percent and that Soviet country is causing us a good deal of trouble tonight.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want to make sure that it stays in that relationship.

speaker: kennedy
text: I don't want to see the day when it's sixty percent of ours, and seventy and seventy-five and eighty and ninety percent of ours, with all the force and power that it could bring to bear in order to cause our destruction.

speaker: kennedy
text: Secondly, the Vice President mentioned medical care for the aged.

speaker: kennedy
text: Our program was an amendment to the Kerr bill.

speaker: kennedy
text: The Kerr bill provided assistance to all those who were not on Social Security.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think it's a very clear contrast.

speaker: kennedy
text: In 1935, when the Social Security Act was written, ninety-four out of ninety-five Republicans voted against it.

speaker: kennedy
text: Mr. Landon ran in 1936 to repeal it.

speaker: kennedy
text: In August of 1960, when we tried to get it again, but this time for medical care, we received the support of one Republican in the Senate on this occasion.

speaker: kennedy
text: Thirdly, I think the question before the American people is: as they look at this country and as they look at the world around them, the goals are the same for all Americans.

speaker: kennedy
text: The means are at question.

speaker: kennedy
text: The means are at issue.

speaker: kennedy
text: If you feel that everything that is being done now is satisfactory, that the relative power and prestige and strength of the United States is increasing in relation to that of the Communists; that we've b- gaining more security, that we are achieving everything as a nation that we should achieve, that we are achieving a better life for our citizens and greater strength, then I agree.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think you should vote for Mr. Nixon.

speaker: kennedy
text: But if you feel that we have to move again in the sixties, that the function of the president is to set before the people the unfinished business of our society as Franklin Roosevelt did in the thirties, the agenda for our people - what we must do as a society to meet our needs in this country and protect our security and help the cause of freedom.

speaker: kennedy
text: As I said at the beginning, the question before us all, that faces all Republicans and all Democrats, is: can freedom in the next generation conquer, or are the Communists going to be successful? That's the great issue.

speaker: kennedy
text: And if we meet our responsibilities I think freedom will conquer.

speaker: kennedy
text: If we fail, if we fail to move ahead, if we fail to develop sufficient military and economic and social strength here in this country, then I think that uh - the tide could begin to run against us.

speaker: kennedy
text: And I don't want historians, ten years from now, to say, these were the years when the tide ran out for the United States.

speaker: kennedy
text: I want them to say these were the years when the tide came in; these were the years when the United States started to move again.

speaker: kennedy
text: That's the question before the American people, and only you can decide what you want, what you want this country to be, what you want to do with the future.

speaker: kennedy
text: I think we're ready to move.

speaker: kennedy
text: And it is to that great task, if we're successful, that we will address ourselves.

speaker: moderator
text: Thank you very much, gentlemen.

speaker: moderator
text: This hour has gone by all too quickly.

speaker: moderator
text: Thank you very much for permitting us to present the next president of the United States on this unique program.

speaker: moderator
text: I've been asked by the candidates to thank the American networks and the affiliated stations for providing time and facilities for this joint appearance.

speaker: moderator
text: Other debates in this series will be announced later and will be on different subjects.

speaker: moderator
text: This is Howard K. Smith.

speaker: moderator
text: Good night from Chicago.
